content: The "Social Security Act Amendments of 1994" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 simplifies employment taxes on domestic services by coordinating the collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. The "Social Security Act Amendments of 1994" coordinates the collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. Returns for domestic service employment taxes are filed on a calendar year basis, with no deposit requirements, and subject to estimated tax provisions for the employer's taxable year. The "Social Security Act Amendments of 1994" coordinate domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. Adjustments are made for tax amounts under section 6654(d)(2) and a transitional rule applies for taxable years beginning in 1994. Domestic service employment taxes include taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. Domestic service employment taxes include taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home, excluding certain services as defined in section 3121(g)(5). Regulations may exempt employers liable for other employment taxes from this section. The Secretary has the authority to prescribe necessary regulations for this purpose. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements with states to collect unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. Taxes collected under these agreements are treated as domestic service employment taxes for coordination with income taxes. The Secretary can enter agreements with states to collect unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. The term 'State' is defined as per section 3306(j)(1). ALLOCATIONS TO FEDERAL DISABILITY INSURANCE TRUST FUND. Section 201(b)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to adjust the allocation with respect to wages, specifying percentages for different time periods. Section 201(b)(2) is also amended to adjust the allocation with respect to self-employment income for taxable years beginning after a certain date. The amendments to the Social Security Act adjust the allocation of wages and self-employment income percentages for different time periods. A study on rising costs of disability benefits will be conducted by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the factors contributing to the increasing costs of disability benefits from the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. This study will analyze the impact of rising numbers of benefit applications, higher benefit allowances, and decreased benefit terminations, as well as identify underlying trends responsible for these changes. The Secretary will report the study results on disability benefit costs to Congress by December 31, 1995, including any recommended legislative changes. SEC. 4. Nonpayment of benefits to individuals confined in criminal cases pursuant to conviction or by court order based on findings of insanity. Section 202(x) of the Social Security Act is amended to include certain inmates of publicly funded institutions. This applies to individuals confined in jail, prison, or other penal institutions for offenses resulting in imprisonment for more than 1 year, or those confined by court order in an institution at public expense due to being found guilty but insane. The amendment to Section 202(x) of the Social Security Act includes individuals found not guilty by reason of insanity or deemed incompetent to stand trial for offenses punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year. The amendment also applies to individuals confined in publicly funded institutions under the jurisdiction of the agency. The Social Security Act is amended to include individuals not guilty by reason of insanity or deemed incompetent to stand trial for offenses punishable by over 1 year in publicly funded institutions under agency jurisdiction. Amendments to Sections 226 and 226A specify that monthly benefits under sections 202 or 223 not payable under section 202(x) do not meet requirements for certain individuals. The amendments made by this section specify that monthly benefits under sections 202 or 223 not payable under section 202(x) do not meet requirements for certain individuals, effective for benefits starting 90 days after the enactment of the Act.
